<instruction>

It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.

<target_code>
Here is the code of alloc:
```c
static int alloc(void)
{
	void *ptr;

	ptr = metal_allocate_memory(1000);
	if (!ptr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "failed to allocate memory\n");
		return errno;
	}

	metal_free_memory(ptr);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function alloc:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The provided source contains only the alloc function and the metal_log macro definition relevant to calls from alloc. Recursion (Rule 17.2) would arise only if any called routine invoked alloc (directly or indirectly). Therefore the call sites in alloc (metal_allocate_memory, metal_free_memory, metal_log) and the macro expansion elements that can call functions (metal_fmt and _metal.common.log_handler) are the only fragments that need investigation. Other parts of the snippet (local variable declaration, returning errno or 0) cannot cause recursion and thus do not need to be investigated.
